title: 114_hr2856
content: The "Citizen Empowerment Act of 2015" is cited as the short title. Part III of title 5, United States Code, is amended by adding a new chapter 79A for services to members of the public. The "Citizen Empowerment Act of 2015" adds new procedures for in-person and telephonic interactions conducted by executive branch employees. Definitions for "telephonic" and "State" are provided. Employees must record enforcement actions during interviews, audits, investigations, or inspections related to Federal violations. The "Citizen Empowerment Act of 2015" allows individuals to make audio recordings of interactions related to potential Federal violations. Federal employees conducting such interactions may also record them after informing the individual. The "Citizen Empowerment Act of 2015" allows individuals to record interactions with Federal employees, who must provide a transcript upon request. Employees must also inform individuals of their rights before any official interaction. The "Citizen Empowerment Act of 2015" allows individuals to record interactions with Federal employees. Separate notifications are required for separate violations. Representatives can make audio recordings on behalf of individuals during interactions with Executive agencies. The "Citizen Empowerment Act of 2015" allows individuals to record interactions with Federal employees. Individuals have the right to receive transcripts or copies of audio recordings. They must receive the same notice as the individual involved and have the same rights regarding audio recordings. Any recordings or transcripts made are the property of the individual. This section does not create a private right of action. The "Citizen Empowerment Act of 2015" allows individuals to record interactions with Federal employees, with exceptions for classified information, public safety, and criminal investigations conducted by Federal law enforcement officers. Employees of an Executive agency can determine exceptions for in-person or telephonic interactions and must notify individuals who would normally be allowed to record such interactions. This section supersedes certain laws related to recording interactions and violators will face disciplinary action. The analysis for part III of title 5, United States Code, is amended by inserting after the item relating to chapter 79 the following provision. "Inserting provision for services to members of the public under chapter 79A, titled 7921."
